main_definition: As used as an abbreviation, ASCII stands for 'American Standard Code for Information Interchange', a character encoding standard that represents text in computers.

meanings_and_examples.example: The ASCII code uses 7 bits to represent each character, allowing for 128 possible characters (2^7 = 128).
When typing the letter 'A', you are inputting its ASCII code, which is 65.
Originally developed for telecommunications and early computer systems in North America.

meanings_and_examples.definition: The earliest form of ASCII, sometimes called '7-bit ASCII', which includes control characters along with printable ones.
meanings_and_examples.example: Control codes like carriage return (CR) and line feed (LF) are part of the 7-bit ASCII set.

meanings_and_examples.definition: An extended version of ASCII that uses 8 bits, known as 'Extended ASCII' or 'Eight-Bit ASCII'.
meanings_and_examples.example: This allows for additional characters such as accented letters and other symbols, expanding the original set to include up to 256 different codes.

meanings_and_examples.definition: A misnomer used interchangeably with '7-bit ASCII' despite originally referring to an eight-bit format.
meanings_and_examples.example: Many people mistakenly use the term '8-bit ASCII' when they actually mean 7-bit ASCII.
